stem: The nurse is caring for a client with severe ARDS on a high-PEEP ventilator protocol. Based on the documentation, match each ventilator setting or intervention to its primary physiological intent.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00: Client (44y/o female) with COVID-19 related ARDS. Currently paralyzed and sedated.
08:30: SpO2 has dropped to 86% despite FiO2 of 0.80.
09:00: Provider orders an increase in PEEP to 18 cm H2O and a decrease in Tidal Volume to 4 mL/kg.
09:30: Peak inspiratory pressures (PIP) are 38 cm H2O; Plateau pressure is 28 cm H2O.

rationale.correct: PEEP (r1) maintains alveolar patency at the end of expiration, preventing collapse (c1). Low tidal volume (r2) limits lung distension, preventing volutrauma and barotrauma (c2). Conservative fluid management (r3) minimizes fluid accumulation in the lungs, reducing alveolar-capillary leakage (c3). FiO2 (r4) increases the oxygen concentration delivered to the client, improving hypoxemia (c4).
clinicalPearls: In ARDS, increasing oxygen delivery alone is often insufficient; pressure is needed to open fluid-filled alveoli.
Ventilator-Induced Lung Injury (VILI) is a significant contributor to mortality in ARDS.
The goal for plateau pressure is < 30 cm H2O to minimize lung injury.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking PEEP primarily addresses CO2 levels.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: PEEP primarily affects oxygenation (PaO2). Respiratory rate and tidal volume primarily affect CO2 removal.

mnemonic.title: PEEP = Pop
mnemonic.expansion: PEEP Pops the Alveoli Open, preventing collapse.
